reviewText:
Knee Deep is an episodic murder mystery game following three protagonists who come together to solve the murders happening in their hometown of Cypress Knee. The setting is set on a stage and it's really surprising the first time when you see the buildings and environment being built right in front of your very own eyes. You as the player have some control over the three main characters of the play. I say some because I felt as though some of the selections that were given felt forced on me.

Anyways, there are choices you can make (in a form of news reports that you can send to your editor/boss), that will determine how other non-playable actors will react to you.  Now, since there’s only one act, I am not sure how much of an impact my decisions will have on future acts so that is to be determined. I will update as more acts are added.

The characters are quirky, albeit strange at times but they all have unique personalities that set them apart from each other. I mean it’s not every day someone asks you to feed a raw chicken wearing a diaper to an alligator. (However, if this is an everyday occurrence to you, please call me.) Some of the dialogues are funny and the story is engaging. I believe it took me about 3.5 hours to complete the first act so it’s not too long.

I would recommend this game, especially since the price dropped to $9.99. The developers are pretty responsive to their players.

I’m not much for scoring but I suppose I would rate the first act a 7/10.

For your viewing pleasure, I uploaded my playthrough of this game on YouTube.

Knee Deep Playlist

reviewText:
Knee Deep is a highly entertaining and unique adventure game, set on theater stage, whee the acts play out in a typical theater fashion.

You can pick from a wide variety of dialog choices and can have large consequences down the line.
The voice acting is a great addition and the actors give life to the character's through their high-quality voice work.

Music in this game are some of the best and most atmospheric I have heard, in many AAA games on the market.
The graphics are great and have unique art style that really adds to the atmosphere.

Each of the character's have unique personality and personal story lines.
There is a unique blogging mechanic where you can post blog articles that will affect the attitudes of characters that you've dealt with along the way.

+ Unique setting & atmosphere
+ High-quality soundtrack
+ Fully Voiced
+ Multi Choice Dialog
+ Interesting Blog mechanic
+ Unique art style

reviewText:
If you like games that are very focused on dialogue choice and don't mind a bit of jankiness, definitely check this out.

Knee Deep is an ambitious game with lots of unique ideas that're mostly well-executed. The game is presented as a play, with you being the lead actor in it. Not all the three characters that you play are very likeable, but the fact that you do play different people gives you an opportunity to play to varying character tropes and see how they mesh together. What really impressed me the first time playing this game is how the theatre theme is played around with in the visuals, in that locations look like parts of the same theatrical stage, and rotating it is how you transition from one scene to the other. The stage lighting gives the scenes a unique noir look that adds to the atmosphere and masks the relatively mediocre quality of the character models.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward point-and-click adventure stuff. You talk to NPCs, pick what to say, get information accordingly, and then move on to the next scene. Every once in a while, you get to single out a piece of information you either picked up from the world or from a conversation and then publish a report on it. The chosen tone of the report and subject matter affects the way some characters react to you later on. There's a couple of puzzles in there, but they're very minimalistic and obviously not the focus of the game.

The writing is quaint, intriguing, and mostly enjoyable, with some laugh out moments in it. Think Twin Peaks in Florida.

The lack of voice acting might bug some people, but I didn't mind it as much. I had trouble remembering who was who, and voice acting might've helped make the NPCs stick to mind more, but I can't imagine the budget of the game would allow the voice acting to be of a high enough quality to justify it being there.

The music amps up and slows down in just the right places, making the tense scenes even more exciting and the tedious ones bearable. What did take me out of the game a bit is the couple of bugs I had here and there where the characters would just stand there and do nothing, but the game autosaves often enough that it wasn't a big hassle.

Overall I had a great time with the game and can't wait for the second act.

Update: Haven't had the time to play through the second act all the way through yet but from what I've played, the plot is progressing as well as before and the voice acting is decent. Stil, I prefer playing with it turned off since I end up reading the dialog faster than it's being spoken and I'm glad that's an option.

reviewText:
The 4.4 hrs on record was the time that it took me to play through this game once, entirely. I wanted to review this from Act 1, but thought it would be better to save it until Act 3 was released. Now that all the acts have been released and played I figured now was the perfect time.

I personally really enjoyed this game. It's more or less a simplified point-and-click game where all you need to do is really press 1 of 3 buttons to make decisions in game. The characters of this game are also wonderfully written and funny. On top of this, the whole game takes place on a theatre stage with you as an audience member who is also the director (somehow) who decides many of the lines in the game.

I would personally say that Act 1 starts off a little slowly (but considering the game is set on stage like a play, this is expected) in that not much really begins to happen until the very end of Act 1. In my opinion from the second half of Act 2 to Act 3 is where everything ramps up dramatically. To me, the entirety of Act 3 was the best part of this game.

I'd recommend this game to you if you're looking for an episodic style game where you don't need to be paying attention 100% of the time as there are (thankfully) no quick time events.

My only complaint would MAYBE be the current price of it. It was £10.99 (UK, full price) at the original date of posting this review, and for something that took 4.4hrs to complete. But then again, you get SO MUCH of that value in Act 3 alone. A definite recommendation from me!

reviewText:
Knee Deep is a bizarre game from its artstyle, narrative, and themes, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing.
Knee Deep tells the tale of three different characters all investigating an apparent suicide. The story takes place in the back waters of swampland Florida. There are all sorts of strange characters all with possibly shady pasts and even shadier motives. From Remy who keeps telling you useless facts, to the strange religion that seemingly is connected to everybody. These characters and interactions is what makes Knee Deep rich. The basic mechanics of the game are simple, this is a visual novel with an interesting aesthetic. You go through the game talking to many characters trying to find out what really is going on. What makes Knee Deep unique is that you form the narrative in many ways, from inner monologue to the back story of certain characters. Things can play out many different ways and it adds a lot of replay value. Occasionally I found the animations and the way conversations ended rather odd. This could be due to Knee Deep being a stageplay that you are watching. As far from a technical standpoint everything works well but increasing the shadow quality of the game caused massive frame drops. This became noticeable and I had to lower the quality to get a smooth game. In all this isn't your usual style of Visual novel, It tries to be different for better or worse. If you come into this expecting a traditional visual novel or something more akin to Telltales games, you may be disappointed. On the other hand if you approach this, curious about weird characters and an unusual murder mystery you might enjoy Knee Deep. It also helps that there is two more acts coming that are completely free with the purchase of the game.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/rgfqwGuS-ik
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

As with a good film, I'm swept up in the story and the mechanics of its telling. I really wanted to sit through the credits that cleverly display when you choose a bathroom break" at the end of the Act.  I'm definitely looking forward to Acts 2 and 3 but as importantly
date:
the next project this team tackles.  I hope they can remain viable.  I've been a gamer for over 50 years and it's rare to see a game that so expertly captures my other passions: movies and theater.  I've enjoyed such cinematic games as Life is Strange but Knee Deep nails the emotional experience evoked by the best of the arts.  It is a gaming masterpiece.

Update:

reviewText:
This is a game for those who love a good story: Complex and believable characters struggle with seemingly insurmountable odds. In classic mystery fashion, our three main investigators start with a seemingly simple suicide, only to unearth a snakes’ den of unsavory characters and forces. Like any good old ingrown community, everyone has an intertwined, violent and/or illegal backstory.

The overall plot backbone is constant, but your conversation and reporting choices open unique subplots and relationship angles: Will he make his cocaine pickup? Will one main character expose another’s dark past? Who lives and who dies? I’ve enjoyed playing through the game several times, trying to uncover new story angles and clues. One thing is for certain, the Act 1 conclusion was completely unexpected and has me dying (no pun) to get my hands on Acts 2 & 3.

This is NOT a game for world explorers or physical clue gumshoes. The designers hold to the stage metaphor and focus your attention on one scene at a time. The 3D world is stage-minimalistic. The sets and lighting nicely capture the nightmarish quality of a backwater town on a hot, muggy night. The 3D characters and their animations are simple but effective. The music was a pleasant surprise for me — haunting and ear-worm worthy.

I enjoy a game with great replay value, and this one lets me explore the consequences of risky convesational styles. I catch glimpses here in Act 1; ultimately, it'll be interesting to see how Acts 2 & 3 bear out the fruits of my game play.

reviewText:
ACT 1 REVIEW:  (Also Act 2 Review below)

Knee Deep is an absorbing world which introduces you to three characters you will play and a dark, steamy florida night, complete with cricket sounds and twangy soundtrack.  I emerged, several hours later, pondering the clues I had uncovered and wondering what will happen next? An exciting, well-staged cliffhanger at the end of this episode got my pulse racing as events rapidly escalated to an unexpected conclusion.
I love this theatrical premise, with gorgeous sets and lighting, and I find the characters fun to play. There are choices to make which influence how other characters will respond to you (whether they will give you much information, for example), but you really cannot fail at this game, which encourages you to take risks and experiment. The game conveniently stores discovered information and clues for you in an easily accessible journal which you can refer to at any time. I found this particularly helpful as there is a lot going on in this first episode.
Cannot wait for the next installment and glad to hear it will be out in just a few months.  Meanwhile, I will be playing this again and making different choices, just to see what happens! A game which rewards experimentation and which is, in a word, FUN.

ACT 2 REVIEW:

Knee Deep's Wonderland offers new scenes but continues its strangely addicting combination of murder mystery with witty (often snarky) repartee. I love the option of choosing edgy reporting or weird responses. Why not? It's a game, not real life. I can take risks.
Still in Cypress Knee, that strangely familiar Florida town, but now there is a weirdly creepy fair complete with a  set of rhyming villagers reminiscent of an off-kilter broadway musical. The body count continues to grow as the clues accumulate...
The occasional short interlude of match the patterm" challenge allows a chance to engage a different part of your brain.  This act is well paced and all in all
date: an excellent use of the 90 minutes or so it takes to play it. Great fun all around
recommended: and I look forward to the final act."

reviewText:
I had a great time with Knee Deep. It's very much in the spirit of Telltale's iconic Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us games, using well-written (and frequently hilarious) dialogue-branch gameplay to further the narrative.

The big thing that struck me was Knee Deep's staging and production design. It's a modestly sized project, but you can tell a lot of thought went into how each scene transitions from one to the next through clever lighting and inspired set design. Buildings spiral, transform, and rotate to take you to each new location, creating a gorgeously fun ballet out of limited art assets.

If I have any gripes at all, it's that I found the swelling cast of characters tough to tell apart after a while. Since many of the scenes are told through static, stage-play inspired shots, it was tough to get a good look at anyone's face up close. I would have loved to have seen an occasional close-up during heated moments to build some intimacy and tension.

Very much looking forward to Act II!

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/fM1hfYB9XWA

Knee Deep is a point and click adventure game which takes place in Cypress Knee with a huge emphasis on the fact that it's a play on a movie set with backdrops and sets being built as the game goes along.

While the game has no voice acting, it makes up with it with lore and dialogue choices to allow you to immerse yourself into the characters shoes even if the environment juxtaposes this.

I found the music and ambient sounds to be top notch and really helped  enhance the mood of the story and allows for crucial decision making to be made more obviously prominent alongside visual prompts.

Overall based on my first impressions, If you like games with a fourth wall element to them, make your choices seem notable with a lot of player decisions and a game with an intriguing mystery and is able to keep that intrigue then this game is for you!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Act 2 Review

Simply put Act 2 feels a lot like the first Act delivering more twists, turns and the addition of voice acting makes for a really enjoyable experience. My only gripe with the act is that it felt a little short.

If you want to hear some voice acting the video below is the start of Act 2 for those interested.

reviewText:
An incredibly addicting and fast-paced choice-driven" gaming experience! Knee-Deep is a great spin on any choice-driven game I've played in the past instead of being a game with a mash of button combo specfic commands or complex actions you choose the fate of your characters' friends/personality/ending on your choices of how they talk/interact with other characters.

What makes Knee-Deep so very special and beautiful is the setting and environment as the game takes place on a very dimnensional theatre stage -- as scenes change lights will dim for the new scene to be lit in the background and the current character will walk/transition to the next scene which unfolds much like at a real play - it's simply beautiful in these transitions and in the lightning/environments - I've never seen or played anything like it.

There are over-the-top speeches in some scenes that rhyme that really sink in the "theatre" experience that I think it could've done without but these also didn't hurt the story. The ending seemed a bit fast and abrupt but the whole story was fast-paced in general (I usually like this speed). The game takes about 4 hours to play. Absoultey worth it! I'd love to see a similar game but with a less southern theme ;) (perhaps something in the city of Boston..hint hint ).

First played at PAX East this weekend and put it in my list of games to buy and beat after playing a taste at their booth.

*SPOILER ALERT*
Perhaps I missed it but never found out who "ANONYMAUS" was..."

reviewText: What did I just play?, This is not by any stretch of the imagination a game, This is an Interactive play, At no point in the game do you take control of any characters, Your only task in the game is to choose dialogue choices and affect how the story turns out in the end, And there are a few puzzles thrown in which are very easy to solve.\nSo did I not like this Play? No it's very entertaining and a great concept and application, Watching the stages move and swoop into view never got old, and the set design was very good, But the character models let the side down a bit, The story was good but nothing epic, But it was pulled off with such charm in the concept of a play that it made up for it's short comings, If I could have directly controlled the actors and played detective and gone to the different scenes of my own volition I would have been more pleased with it, The first act seemed a lot longer than the 2nd and third acts, It took me six hours to play through it and it was enjoyable and different and for that I applaud the Devs for doing something different. Replay value virtually Nil unless you have a very bad memory. 7/10.

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but here I am due to the power of this game.  Words like unique get bandied about way too much.  But in a gameworld of lookalikes and cookie cutters gameplay, this title is UNIQUE!

It is unlike anything on the market.  It is set up as if it was a play.  And it plays out like a big stage production.  Everything from the style of the excellently voiced dialogue, to the sounds of stage props and backgrounds being worked into place to the actors' feet on wood stage floors reinforces this.

Until the devs choose to reveal the culprits, the game is a complete mystery whodunnit!  Bravo!  As I said, the voice acting is convincing, the music soundtrack is so perfectly matched to the setting and the story parts, no major studio could have done it better.

The story sucks you in, and indeed, I found myself forgetting that it was a play at times.  Overall, this is nothing short of BRILLIANT!!!

reviewText:
Having just finished Act 1, I can say that Knee Deep was a really fun ride. The basics are that you investigate a little racist roadside attraction that has become a hotbed of nationwide attention after an actor seemingly commits suicide there. There are three main characters you control in different scenes" of the play and you write an update for your character's boss (or audience) using facts you gather.

+ The writing is great. I laughed out loud several times choosing the "interesting" dialogue choices
+ The story and characters are engaging. The ending had a lot happen at once which is overwhelming but I am invested in Act 2 and want to see how they develop it. Going to go through again to see how much the choices affect outcomes.
+ The setting and story device are unique and have more depth than I originally thought in opening scenes

- No voice acting. This was very apparent in the opening scenes but I honestly quickly got over it soon after. I think the game would be improved by it but not significantly. I am one of those types of people that reads dialogue and moves to the next before actors can fully speak their lines in RPGs anyway."

reviewText:
I’ve enjoyed my time with Knee Deep so far, despite some small negatives. The rate at which characters are introduced during the beginning of the game can be a little overwhelming as you try to get to grips with their names and backstories; but it’s hard to resist digging deeper into their answers to uncover their stories and grudges against each other. Some have criticised the visual style by claiming that it’s outdated; but what better way to portray a backwater town far past its heyday than to use an artistic style which evokes the same feeling?

If you’re not a fan of releases in the same vein as Telltale Games’ titles, it’s likely that Knee Deep’s gameplay style won’t be for you. But if you love a crime-thriller full of twists and turns and colourful characters, there’s plenty here to keep you occupied for a couple of hours.

Full details can be found here:
http://1001up.com/2015/09/21/preview-knee-deep/

reviewText:
This review was written for FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[freedomcgc.com].
DISCLAIMER: This is a review of the first episode. No score will be given. A full review of the entire season will follow once all three episodes have been released.

It’s a good thing that I’m playing this game on a hot summer evening. It’s also interesting that I live just a few miles away from one of the largest swampland areas in Europe and the humidity, as always, is unbearable. It’s just curious that there are no mosquitoes tonight. All in all, a perfect situation to immerse myself into Knee Deep, a self-proclaimed swamp noir in three acts. And I am immersed in a matter of seconds. The first thing that strikes me is the music, a brilliantly moody mixture of American folk and blues. I start the game up and I am immediately seated in a theater. I silence my mobile phone out of respect for the actors. As the curtain rises on the stage, I find myself in a backwater Florida town of Cypress Knee. It’s a grim start as a washed-up actor has hanged himself from a tower next to a local inn.

It is at that time that I am called up to control the story. Even though a wider narrative is in place, the player is able to move the story along through the actions of three distinct characters. Romana Teague, a 20-year-old blogger kicks things off as she decided to report on the apparent suicide. Then there’s Jack Bellet, a local reporter whose career and marriage is falling apart. Lastly, private investigator K.C. Gaddis, hired by the film studio to look into Tag Kern’s suicide, arrives on the scene as well. Not all is as it seems in Cypress Knee and each character will stumble onto different pieces of information as they survey the surroundings and talk to the locals. Certain critical choices will affect relationships with other characters. Also, as you uncover certain details, you can choose which story to run and what spin to put on it. Whether you choose to keep things grounded, put an edgy spin on a story, or go all out sensationalist, it will have an effect on the narrative and other characters. What I found most compelling was the ability to choose the playable characters’ past and motivations and that is something I hope to see more of in upcoming episodes.

The overall story is certainly intriguing with all manner of seedy and eccentric characters. However, the writing is a bit of a hit-and-miss. Romana in particular comes off as rather obnoxious too often in an attempt to be snarky and that’s definitely not a trait you want the lead character to have. Some situations are realized to great effect while others fall flat. The gameplay revolves around choosing responses when interacting with characters and choosing which story to write and what spin to put on it. There are only two puzzles in the game and they’re an extremely basic affair of putting several puzzle pieces together. It is clear that the gameplay in Knee Deep takes a backseat to storytelling and atmosphere. And the atmosphere is truly palpable.

Aside from the already mentioned brilliant soundtrack, certain graphical effects are pulled off masterfully as well. While the graphics are technically rather modest, the slick utilization of a theater stage makes up for it. The game takes place during a single evening and the stage is mostly very dark with a few lights coming on to highlight points of interest. As the lead characters enter buildings, the outer walls and ceilings rise up to reveal the interior. Also, as you go from one location to another, the entire stage rotates and changes the backdrop. It’s truly an inspired series of effects that completely nail the vibe of both a dark stage and a small Florida swamp town.

The first act will take you about 2 hours to finish, so it’s a bit short even for an episodic game. I played through it a second time to see how different choices affect the story and to get some achievements. The remaining two acts will follow at an undetermined date. The end of Act 1 brings closure to this particular part of the story, but there are still things left to uncover.

THE VERDICT

Knee Deep Act 1: Wonderland is a solid start with an intriguing story, lots of choices and interesting characters. A bit too light on gameplay, it does manage to make up for it mostly due to its fantastic presentation which masterfully uses graphical effects and music to provide a strong sense of place.

reviewText:
I really had to think hard about whether or not I recommend this (again wishing for the neutral thumb!) and ended up coming up on the pro side with a few caveats.

+ Unique setting and atmosphere (feels like playing a session of Fiasco or watching a Cohen bros film set in Florida)
+ Story keeps you guessing
+ Memorable protagonists
+ Interesting theatre trappings (the set pieces were super cool)
+ Fun mechanic for publishing (choosing your clue and a stance and then seeing people's reactions)

- Characters take a million years to walk between scene transitions
- Some mini games are fun but most are not (one is so miserable that it has a skip button), it would be nice to be able to skip them on replay
- Seems like there are more choices than there are. Playing through a second time, I tried to have a character say 'no' near the end only to have this but thou must!" conversation until the only option left to choose was "OK"
- The 'quirky' business with Romana (the female character) felt really off a lot of the time - like sometimes she would just shout "pineapple!" and leave the scene
- A little too much edgy for edgy's sake stuff in there (the disgraced professor character was a little bit too much for no reason for me and some characters are pretty flat stereotypes)
- Acts 2 and 3 are shorter and have fewer options in them than Act 1
date: seems like maybe budget constraints\n- Checkpoint system is really robust but it would be nice to be able to save manually
recommended: especially while going for those Opto test achievements"

reviewText:
I liked this a lot. It's a strange idea to make a game which pretends it's a play, but they managed to make it work quite well. That kind of makes it easier to accept that the story changes according to to your choices, because even the game doesn't pretend it actually happened. It's also funny how they wasted so much time in making the backgrounds look like fake sets and yet made them unrealistically huge on purpose, and how everyone sounds like they are just acting, again completely on purpose...

Some parts of the story were pretty stupid and not as serious as one might expect from the beginning, but I'm not really complaining since I was entertained thorough.

I've only played this once, so I don't know how much your choices really affect the story, but I'm pretty sure they change at least a couple of things quite significantly. There are lots of dialogue options at least, so I think I'll play this again at least once at some point.

reviewText:
Knee Deep is a wonderfully compelling mystery with amazing characters that embraces the brand of weirdness you can only find in Florida. It makes even the most outlandish characters and situations work well, though it does stretch the limits of your suspension of disbelief.
But more than that, it made me love the characters and I hope Prologue Games keeps them around for their next games. I want to know more of Romana, K.C. and Jack!

reviewText:
I entered a raffle at the devs' booth at PAX East 2016 and won a key to play the game for free. I enjoyed the little bit of time I spent with it during the con and intended to complete the game afterwards and leave a review, especially since I won the raffle (i NEVER win things!).

+ interesting visual effects

- awkward models
- slow pace
- not enough character development? too many characters i didn't care about

I'd recommend the game to those itching for a noir story to follow along.

reviewText: Knee Deep is an ambitious take on the interactive movie (Telltale 'em up) formula. The twist here is instead of being inside a TV show, you choose your own adventure inside a stage play. This allows for some novel cinematography and very clever, well-paced scene transitions. The mechanics are no different to anything else in the genre, but by embracing the idea of the player being the director rather than an actor, the more tedious walking from point A to B aspects of the genre are removed, which lets you focus on the story.\n\nUnfortunately, although the plot has all the right ingredients - corruption, rednecks, mythology and a down on his luck private ♥♥♥♥ - it never quite comes together. I am not sure if it is the direction of the voice acting or the script itself, but it feels like the characters never really react to one another. The dialog is somehow missing whimsy, given the absurdity of the whole setup. The second and third acts go a bit more in a self-consciously theatrical direction, but it's not enough. That's a bit of a shame, because as mentioned the concept is incredibly strong, and both the set design and the music is excellent. It's definitely worth giving this a playthrough just for the ideas it brings to the table. I look forward to whatever the devs come up with next.

reviewText:
Fantastic.
Absolutely one of the best game I've aver played.
To me, its a sort of indie ALAN WAKE!
The idea of getting player inside a theater play is intriguing and terrific.
You start the game thinking about next steps and clues to look for but soon after the game shows you all its potential.
You're the director. You decide what happens next.
Anything matters more than getting the story to work.
And to work well.
Characters are delightful.
Very humanized and three dimensional.
They're not just some character, no. You feel they're actors, thanks to the great voice acting!
That being said ... well ... the play is in your very hands.
You're in charge of making things happen.
And what happens is brilliant!
Style is brilliant.
Voice acting is brilliant.
Everything is brilliant.
The story is terrific!
It sounds like TWIN PEAKS and ALAN WAKE!
But also reminds of all those horror B movies of the 80's.
And, of course, it links with SHAKESPEARE and THE ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW.
It is filled with developers' passion.
You feel it.
And you get it when you experience some of the best scene in the three acts.
Last but not least, it really is a very passionate homage to theater and its mechanics.
The beginning of Act 2 is just ... well ... the best!
And, of course ... making actors to be followed by lights or not is such a great choice!
It takes gaming to a next level, mixing it with theater and drama.
AMAZING!
10/10

reviewText:
Really cool atmosphere. I enjoy playing multiple characters, but I wish I had the chance to learn more about them as I'm playing through the plot. I'll probably wait a few days and play through again with different choices, see how they affect people's reactions.

I'm looking forward to seeing how the story threads tie together in future parts.

It's a bit spendy for ~2h gameplay (act 1 only), but I still recommend it when a sale comes up.

reviewText:
With one fairly quick, but thoroughly enjoyable run through of Act I, I feel like Knee Deep is a game I never knew I wanted to play.

I may be subject to some genre bias, narrative adventure is something I genuinely enjoy, but I feel Knee Deep has performed admirably in this regard. The characters are engaging, if not always likeable, the story is superbly written and the mystery itself enough to make me want to keep digging.

When it comes to negative points. If you're after action, or a rich puzzle-filled experience, as some other adventure games showcase, Knee Deep may not be for you. As I'm sure it says in the description somewhere, and probably another review, the game is about choice, dialogue, and character (As I see). The dialogue also falls into a similar problem I found in L.A. Noire (Admittedly a very different game) where the dialogue choices you make may not always be quite clear on the tone you're about to throw at a witness/friend/boss. But all in all, very minor problems.

The choice of graphical style is quirky, but fits seamlessly into the tone of the story as it's written. Witty dialogue, wacky backdrops, and a story and characters that could really have come from a Florida backwater. With only one playthrough of one act under my belt, I'm sure that Knee Deep is money well spent.

reviewText: Knee deep is a great, noir, dialogue-adventure game.  It contrasts with the different Telltale series because you don't really move your character or collect items.  You just choose what the different characters are doing, and what they say in a given moment.  You watch the characters and environments morph as though the game takes place on a stage, which is actually pretty novel and entertaining.  This game really excelled at walking the line between bizarre and emotionally-engaging.  Many adventure games which stray into bizarre territory lose me, such as D4.  I was interested in what happened to these characters and this strange town, and the game's relatively short 4-5 hour playtime ensured that it didn't wear out its welcome.

reviewText:
The Pros -

Interesting Noir story line.
Neat premise (Inside a theatre and you get to control the actors responses)
Good music
Nice art style
Player choice affects gameplay.

The Cons -

Not voice acted. I feel like this game would be AMAZING if it had voice acting. As it is now I struggled to remember everyone's name (Apart from the very Major characters) and missed some of the story because it is hard to guage someone's reaction from a straight text of what is being said.

It is hard to see where a certain conversation thread is going to lead based on your 3-4 choices. I realize there doesn't need to be a full transcript of what they are going to say, but a little more info might be good?

Short (For the moment)
It is supposed to be 3 acts so I will change this once those other 2 acts come out. But at the moment is $10 US for a 2 hour experience.

Overall I enjoyed the game and would reccomend it to anyone who enjoys Noir style storytelling and visual novel/choose your own adventure games.

reviewText:
I wish I was able to give this game more credit, because when it does things right it's very enjoyable.  However, there's enough to hold the game back that I wish there was a neutral thumb.  It's not strictly bad, but there are some serious negatives.

The game is a select your own branching narrative styled game that follows a murder mystery taking place in the Florida Swamps.  Think Carl Hiaasen like feel if it were a novel.  For the first act of the game it seems to follow this pretty well, a strong drama with some action and black humor to keep things varied.  But the next two acts seem to lose sense of what the game was about and the final act feels like it is rushing to close up all the loose ends the first two acts used to keep us wanting more.

Positives:

+Technical: The game worked just fine on my computer.  No problems to speak of.
+Soundtrack:  The soundtrack is amazing and easily worth listening to on it's own.  It cements the feel and tone of the game.
+Time:  If you want a quick play, you can easily knock this game out in a few hours.
+Sense of Humor:  The game isn't afraid to poke fun at itself.
+Visual style:  The game looks great and has an original feel thanks to the stage like atmosphere.

Negative:

-Dialogue:  Ranges from okay" to "please stop talking."
-Storyline:  Starts strong
date: but then it seems like it can't decide if it wants to be funny or not.  Rushes into an ending.\n-Time:  If you wanted a longer game
recommended: look elsewhere.\n-Characters: While interesting at times
hoursPlayed:
they vary from stereotype to just nonsense.
-replayability:  few of the choices truly seem meaningful and there is little incentive to play again after the first time.

Ultimatly the game isn't worth the $19.99 it has right now.  Wait for it to go on sale and only if this genre of game is something you really love."

reviewText: I've seen Knee Deep compared to a few things, and there's something to the comparisons.  It plays like a distilled Telltale game, where you spend all your time choosing dialogue and investigating, and no time wondering around or exploring.  It's got a backward-looking narravite structure, cutting to police interviews after the fact.  It's tone is somewhat like Twin Peaks, in that it's dark but with a touch of zany comedy.  All in all, it's got a clever premise that the game is a staged play, great environments, and great music.  And it doesn't ovestay it's welcome, which I appreciate, as a time-pressed gamer.
